This is the motivation that led her to request a loan for 1,500 Peruvian soles from Edpyme Alternativa.  She will use the money to buy clothes to sell and also balanced feed with which to fatten her animals.

Leonor is a long-standing client of our institution and she has a good credit record as she has shown responsibility in paying back her loans.

loans.use: to buy clothes

loans.name: Cresencia

texts.en:
Cresencia is 26 years old and has two children.

Cresencia works hard to provide for her family. She runs a business buying and selling charcoal in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 16,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional sacks of charcoal to sell.

Cresencia has borrowed and paid back 15 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running her charcoal business for five years and earns additional income from selling gasoline.

Cresencia aspires to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: To purchase additional sacks of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Merry Christ

texts.en:
Merry Christ is 32 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with three children. 

Merry Christ has a pigpen that sells grown and matured pigs. She has had this business for five years. She has requested a loan for PHP 15,000 to buy animal feeds for the pigs.

Merry Christ has been a member of HSPFI since 2011. In the future, Merry Christ hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy animal feeds for her pigs

loans.name: Erick Josué

texts.es: "Dentro de 5 años me imagino como director o coordinador de un área de Formulación y Planificación de Proyectos, me inspira poder apoyar a mi madre quién siempre me ha apoyado a mí cuando más lo he necesitado. estoy interesado en la pedagogía, éstos conocimientos son parte de un ciclo de retroalimentación entre profesor y alumno. Al iniciar la universidad tuve problemas de integrarme con mis compañeros, pues sentía que no formaba parte de ningún grupo y sólo con el tiempo lo pude superar."
texts.en: "Within five years, I imagine myself to be a director or coordinator in the area of Development and Project Planning.  I am inspired to help my mother, who has always helped me when I've needed it.  I am interested in education, and knowledge is part of a feedback loop between teacher and student.  When I started at university, I had problems getting on with my classmates as I felt I wasn't part of any group, and only with time was I able to overcome this."

loans.use: to pay for a Masters degree in Project Management.

loans.name: Annie

texts.en:
Annie is 64 years old and lives in Barnersville. She is married and has five children between 22 to 40 years old. Her husband is a businessman. 

For the past thirty-five years she has been selling charcoal, and she is requesting a loan to purchase more charcoal for her business. A problem she faces is that she has more customers than inventory. She likes her business because it has helped her to build her house. 

She hopes to build a community school and a clinic.

loans.use: to purchase more charcoal for her business

loans.name: Gemalyn

texts.en:
Gemalyn is 40 years old and married. She has 3 children ages 21, 19 and 17. Gemalyn and her husband are both farmers. They own the land that they till, located in Sto. Niño, South Cotabato. Gemalyn helps her husband grow rice and vegetables. She also helps in selling their harvest at the market.

Gemalyn applied for this loan because they need seeds, herbicides and fertilizers. Gemalyn hopes to continue earning from their farm. She also hopes to sustain her children's college education.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, herbicides and fertilizers

loans.name: Gliceria

texts.en:
This is Gliceria, 60, a resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Policarpio, her business partner, and mother to their two children who already have their own families. With her husband, Gliceria manages their own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Gliceria operates a buy and sell business. What she basically does is to buy general merchandise from wholesalers and sells it with a little profit. Her products are children’s clothes, RTW and other products of the like. Customers are attracted to buy due to the low selling prices and the many options she offers. Aside from this, she also operates a small variety store for added income. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 800 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, Gliceria is requesting a PHP35,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy RTW products and merchandise items to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Gliceria hopes to be able to expand her business in the coming years. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional stocks of 'Ready To Wear' merchandise and product items needed in her business.

loans.name: Moustapha

texts.fr: Monsieur Moustapha habite au Sénégal. Il est âgé de 32 ans. Il est célibataire et évolue dans le secteur du commerce plus précisément  dans la vente de friperie.  C’est après avoir perdu son emploi  que son frère  a commencé à lui envoyer des habits de friperie. Son point fort est qu’il vend à des prix abordables qui sont a la portée de toutes les bourses. Il est membre d’un des  guichets  de l’U-IMCEC  depuis mai 2011. Il sollicite un crédit de 500 000frs prévu pour l’achat de plus de marchandises en vue de développer d’avantage son activité de commerce. L’augmentation de ses bénéfices lui permettra de mieux participer dans les dépenses familiales car il vit sous toit de son frère.
texts.en: Moustapha lives in Senegal and is 32 years old. He is single and is developing a trading business, more precisely in the sale of second-hand clothing. When he lost his job, his brother started sending him second-hand clothes. His strength lies in the fact that he sells his goods at affordable prices which are accessible to all budgets. He has been a member of one of the branches of UIMCEC since May 2011. He is requesting a loan of 500,000 francs with which he is planning to buy more goods in order to expand his business. An increase in his profits will allow him to contribute more to family expenses, since he is living in his brother's house.

loans.use: to buy second-hand clothing for resale

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph is 40 years old and married. He has been running a carpentry business for the last three years to support his family. He also practices dairy farming to increase his income. 

Joseph is requesting a loan for  50,000 Kenya shillings, which he will use to buy timber and animal feeds. In the next five years, he wants to expand his business.

loans.use: to purcase timber and animal feeds

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is a 30-year-old woman, married with 3 children, living in Bundibugyo, Uganda. Her family's objectives are to educate the children and improve the family's standard of living.

Jane deals in the purchase and sale of charcoal. She has limited capital to meet the increasing demand of her customers and she would like to get a loan to buy more charcoal for resale

loans.use: to buy charcoal for resale

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en: Evelyn is 30 years old and lives in Tongo, Siquijor. She is married with four school aged children. Evelyn has a general store and earns approximately PHP 1,500 each month doing this type of work. She has requested a loan of PHP 7,000 to purchase more inventory for her general store. Evelyn has been a member of Paglaum Multi Purpose Cooperative for 10 months. In the future, Evelyn hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more inventory for general store

loans.name: Vicky

texts.en:
Vicky has been engaged in her rice farming business for eight years and earns about PHP 32,000 every harvest. She also has a sari-sari store (variety store), based in her home, from which she has been selling groceries for almost six months and earns PHP 800 daily. 

Vicky is willing to work hard every single day to lift her family out of poverty. According to her, through the income generated from her businesses she has been able to give daily allowances to her children, who are currently in school. At this time, she is requesting a loan of PHP 15,000 to purchase seeds and fertilizers to sustain her rice field production. She hopes that she can get the amount she has requested to further develop her business.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and fertilizers to sustain her rice field production.

loans.name: Gabriel Antonio

texts.es:
Don Gabriel,  reside  en Catarina municipio del departamento de Masaya. Es casado y  posee su negocio de compra y venta de artesanía de barro, desde hace 6 años, este se lo heredó su mama y ha continuado con el negocio.

Actualmente está teniendo mucha demanda por la temporada navideña, sus puntos de ventas las tiene en Diriamba, San Marcos, Las Esquinas de Catarina, San Juan de Oriente.  

El crédito lo está solicitando para la compra de jarrones grandes, cuadros de pared, juegos de botellas de barro, hamacas de manila, jarrones de 3 piezas, entre otros.
texts.en: Gabriel resides in Catarina in the department of Masaya. He is married and has had a business buying and selling clay crafts for the past six years. He inherited the business from his mother, who continues with the business. Currently he is experiencing very high demand because of the Christmas season at his sales posts in Diriamba, San Marcos, street corners in Catarina and San Juan de Oriente. He is requesting the loan to purchase large vases, wall paintings, clay bottle games, manilla hammocks, three-piece vase sets, and other items.

loans.use: to purchase large vases, wall paintings, clay bottle games, manilla hammocks, three-piece vase sets, etc.

loans.name: Emprendedores De Vitarte Group

texts.es: El grupo Emprendedores de Vitarte, está conformado por la unión de varias mujeres emprendoras. Todas las integrantes del grupo desarrollan distintas actividades de forma conjunta y solidaria, dentro de un ambiente de compañerismo, respeto y unión. La señora Verónica es una de ellas, tiene 32 años, ella es soltera y tiene 2 hijos que son menores de edad y dependen de ella, se dedica a la venta de Comida hace un año, comenzó por unos  amigos de su localidad, que le pedían que cocinara para ellos. Con esta venta genera los ingresos que pueden pagar los gastos que se da día a día en su hogar, como la compra de los alimentos y de los gastos de colegio que paga mensualmente. Con el reciente préstamo ella quiere formalizar y registrar su pequeño negocio y estar en regla con sus documentos
texts.en:
The Emprendedores de Vitarte group is made up of the union of several women entrepreneurs.  All the members of the group work in different activities in a coordinated and supportive way, in an atmosphere of companionship, respect, and union.

Verónica is one of the women.  She is 32 years old and single, with two minor children who are dependent on her.  She has worked selling food for a year.  She began because of some friends in her community who were asking her to cook for them.  With this sale she generates the income that can pay the daily expenses in her home, such as buying food, and the monthly school expenses she pays.

With the recent loan, she wants to formalize and register her small business and have her documents in order.

loans.use: to buy food.

loans.name: Kimheat's Group

texts.en:
A rural dweller from a village located in the Tbaung Khmum district, Kimheat is 31 years old and has two dependent children who are still in school. She is a farmer and also sells groceries in front of her house to make a living. She has been in this business for several years. She currently earns US$5 per day and is able to save US$2.5 per day.

There are three members in Kimheat's group. She and Neang are the first cycled clients while Pov has been with VisionFund since 2010. Now Kimleat leads this group in applying for a loan with VisionFund. She will use the entire loan of US$300 to buy fertilizer for her farmland and also buy some grocery items e.g., shampoo, biscuits, cooking oil, etc. for her store. She hopes this loan will help her increase her business and make a better living.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for her farmland and some groceries.

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Tbaung Khmum district

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda is 54 years old, residing at Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur. Philippines. Erlinda is married and has two children.

To earn a living, Erlinda owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products. She has been in this business for six years, and from it she earns PHP 3,000 a month. 

She requested a loan of PHP 8,000 to purchase new items so she can expand her product offering. In 2011, Erlinda joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. In the future, Erlinda wants to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand her product offering.

loans.name: Divino Niño Group

texts.es:
El comité “Divino Niño” se encuentra en el primer ciclo del programa de Mujeres Emprendedoras, tiene 12 integrantes, de la zona de Asunción. Todas ellas son mujeres muy trabajadoras  luchadora, que tienen un gran deseo de superación y crecimiento.
Eudelia es una mujer muy sacrificada y trabajadora, ella se dedica al reciclaje de plásticos, botellas, catones y demás. Dice que recorre por las calles buscando esos productos y que acaba el día muy cansada, ya que se levanta muy temprano. Cuenta que está muy orgullosa de lo que hace, pues es un trabajo digno y honesto.
Ella solicita el crédito para la compra de plásticos, pues al revenderlos tendrá un poco más de ganancias. Agradece la oportunidad que recibe por parte de Kiva y fundación paraguaya.
texts.en:
The “Divino Niño” (Divine Child) Group is in their first loan cycle with the Mujeres Emprendedoras (Entrepreneurial Women) program. There are twelve group members from the Asunción area. They are all very hard-working women with a great desire for achievement and growth.

Eudelia is very sacrificial and hard-working. She works recycling plastics, bottles, cardboard, and more. She says she goes through the streets looking for these products and ends the day very tired, since she gets up very early. She shares that she is very proud of what she does, because it is dignified and honest work.

She is asking for a loan to buy plastic products that she can resell to earn a little money. She is thankful for the opportunity she is provided from Kiva and the Paraguayan Foundation.

loans.use: buy plastics for resale

loans.name: Ángel Douglas

texts.es: Ángel Douglas vive junto a su esposa  y dos  hijos. Ángel posee una parcela en la cual  se dedica al cultivo de maíz y frijoles, productos que  posteriormente comercializa en diferentes departamentos del país, obteniendo muy buenas ganancias. Él es una persona muy humilde pero emprendedora quien trabaja muy arduamente día con día. Ángel desea aumentar su cosecha razón por la que solicita un préstamo a INTEGRAL, por medio del cual pueda comprar pesticidas, abono, arados y semillas de frijol y maíz de la mejor calidad para sembrar y así obtener una excelente cosecha. El mayor deseo de Ángel  es mejorar en gran manera  su negocio, garantizando la calidad de su semilla y así satisfacer siempre a sus clientes y así mismo obtener otros nuevos, lo que le permita mejorar  su estabilidad económica.

loans.use: Comprar pesticidas, abono, arados y semillas de frijol para sembrar

loans.name: Sixto Hernandez

texts.en:
Hello, everyone. I’m known as Sixto “The smiley”. I always try to welcome my clients with a smile, and treat them nicely. I have a small store located at the public transportation terminal in Danli. I started out managing my brother’s store, and then I decided to have one of my own. I’ve been able to grow. When I started, I used to rent a space, and later I was able to buy one. That’s where I have the store now. With the income from sales I’m making my business grow, and am able to provide my family with education, healthcare, food, and clothes.

Loan Use: Purchase bread, flour, eggs, refreshments, beans, rice, sugar, coffee, and others.

Hola todos me conocen como Sixto el sonriente, siempre he tratado de atender a mis clientes con una sonrisa y amblemente, tengo un mercadito ubicada en la terminal de trasportes de Danli. Inicie administrando el negocio de mi hermano, luego decidi dedicarme a mi negocio propio y he logrado crecer, comence alquilando local luego compre el propio donde actualmente tengo mi negocio. Con los ingresos que percibo de las ventas estoy logrando que mi negocio crezca y darle a mi familia educacion, salud, alimento y vestuario.

loans.use: Compra de pan, harina, huevos, refrescos, frijoles, arroz, azucar, cafe y otros.

loans.name: Vida

texts.en: Vida sells food called "fufu and soup". This kind of business is locally called a Chop Bar. She had her training from Kraban Support Foundation through the TEACH lending programs. She needs a Kiva loan of $850 to expand her chop bar business in the community.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a new bicycle for his bicycle taxi business

loans.name: Gabriela

texts.es:
Gabriela is married and has two small children. Her husband is a labourer, nevertheless, his salary is not enough to cover all of their household expenses. Because of this lack of funds, Gabriela began to sell cosmetics by catalog 6 years ago. At first, one of her neighbors helped her, but afterwards, Gabriela decided to work alone. Little by little, the number of her customers has grown and she has seen her earnings increase as well.

Today, Gabriela is applying for a loan of $200 which she will re-pay in 3 months. With this loan, she will be able to purchase more merchandise and be able to offer a better service to her customers and continue to see her business grow. You can be a part of the success of this business and the dreams of Gabriela, do not hesitate and decide to loan today.

Translated from Spanish by Kiva Volunteer, Kristin Connor.

Gabriela es casada y tiene dos pequeños hijos, su esposo es obrero, sin embargo, el salario que recibe es insuficiente para cubrir todos los gastos de su hogar, ante esta necesidad Dolores inició con la venta de cosméticos por catálogo desde hace seis años, primero le ayudaba a vender a una de sus vecinas, depuse decidió independizarse y vender por su cuenta poco a poco ha estado ganando más clientes y ha incrementado de manera significativa sus ventas.

En estos momentos, Gabriela solicita un préstamo de $200 dólares, mismos que se compromete a regresar en 3 meses, con esto planea comprar mercancía para poder ofrecer sus clientes un buen servicio y continuar creciendo como hasta ahora. Tú puedes ser parte de este negocio, y de los sueños de Gabriela, no lo dudes más y decídete a apoyarla.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise.

loans.name: Immaculée

texts.fr:
Mrs. Immaculée A., 32, was born in Attitogon (Lakes Province, Togo) where she also attended school. Because of the impossibility of paying school fees, she came to Lomé to go into retail trade in order to earn her living. That is how she began selling onions.

Immaculée is married and mother of four children. Her husband works for a larger company in Lomé but his earnings are not sufficient to support the family, so Immaculée does her part to help earn their livelihood with her little onion business. Quite ambitious, she would like to expand her micro-business by becoming a wholesaler, however this requires a good deal of capital. That is why she is now requesting a loan of US$ 800.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Agée de 32 ans, Madame A. Immaculée est née à Attitogon (Pr Lacs) où elle a fait ses études primaires. Faut de moyens pour poursuivre ses études, elle est venue à Lomé pour faire le commerce afin de subvenir à ses besoins. C’est ainsi qu’elle commença le commerce des oignons.

Mariée, elle est mère de quatre (4) enfants. Son mari travaille dans une société de la place mais le revenu est insuffisant pour les charges de la famille. Ce qui fait que Madame A. Immaculée l’assiste grâce aux revenus de son commerce. Très ambitieuse, elle veut agrandir la taille de son commerce en devenant grossiste. Mais ceci demande beaucoup de moyens financiers. C’est pour cela qu’elle sollicite un apport financier de $800.

loans.use:
Becoming a wholesaler of onions
Achat et vente de sacs d'oignons

loans.name: Shazia

texts.en: My name is Shazia K. and I am the mother of two children. My husband buys second-hand spare parts of various machines and after cleaning them sells them in various nearby cities.  He is not able to earn enough due to high operating costs which can be decreased if the spare parts are bought in bulk. The spare parts bought paying cash and in bulk are cheaper. I am therefore requesting a loan of US$ 300.

loans.use: BUY USED SPARE PARTS IN BULK

loans.name: Umid

texts.en: Umid's business is mainly seasonal. The main trade is done in summer and fall, but in winter before the New Year's holiday and the Islam holiday of Ramazan, his business becomes active. Melons and watermelons are one of the popular things on the holiday table for Tajiks.

loans.use: Trade of melons and watermelons

loans.name: Leyla Corina

texts.es:
Leyla is a woman who has four school-aged children. Her children are the reason that she strives to succeed and why she has worked so hard to offer them a stable family and an education for their future. Leyla Corina has sold beef for 31 years. It's important to point out that this is a good business right now, and her sales have increased considerably through the years. Her initial capital was 10,000 córdobas that she obtained through the support of ther mother.

Leyla Corina has worked with CEPRODEL for 14 months, and she feels very satisfied with the credits offered to her because they have come at opportune moments and have helped her supply what she needs to her business and satisfy her clientele's daily demands. She has a record of 8 credits.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

Leyla es una mujer acompañada con cuatro hijos los cuales se encuentran en la edad escolar. Sus hijos han sido la razón para que ella se superara y por ellos es que ella se ha esforzado, brindándoles así una familia estable y una educación para el futuro de ellos. Desde hace 31 años Leyla Corina se dedicaba a vender carne de res.

Es importante señalar que este es un buen negocio hoy en día en su sector, sus ventas incrementaron considerablemente al paso de los años. Su capital de inicio fue de C$ 10,000 (córdobas) los cuales los obtuvo por aporte de su mamá.

Leyla Corina trabaja con CEPRODEL desde hace 14 meses y se siente muy satisfecha con los créditos otorgados ya que les han sido brindados en el momento oportuno, ayudando así a suplir las necesidades del negocio y satisfacer a diario a su clientela. Ella tiene un record de 8 créditos.

loans.use: Purchase of meat

loans.name: Pron

texts.en: Mrs. Pron N., 44, is a mother of seven children and lives in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She works with her husband, as brokers purchasing coconuts, bananas, and pigs to resell for a profit, earning collectively a profit of around $4 each day. This couple has been in this business since 1996. Three of their children are employed by a garment factory, two are married, and the rest are too young to attend school. Mrs. Pron N. hopes to use this loan to expand her business by purchasing more pigs and fruits.

loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing more pigs and fruits.

loans.name: Glinda

texts.en:
Glinda G. M. D. Redriguez runs a juice bar in the main market of Picota, San Martin. She rents a spot in the market from the town municipality where she serves fresh juices, sandwiches and cakes daily. Glinda has run her business for ten years so she has plenty of experience and many loyal customers.

Glinda is 49 years old, married, and has four children. She loves working and feeding her community delicious meals. Her husband is supportive and they both work hard to send their children to university so their children can have more opportunities in life than they did.

A member of Manuela Ramos and the community bank Los Claveles, Glinda is requesting a loan of S/. 1,000 to invest in her business and repay in 6 months. With this loan, she would like to buy fruit and a new more powerful blender.

loans.use: To buy fruit and a new blender

loans.name: Tony

texts.en: Tony O. is married with 4 children. He is 49 years old and owns a computer center. He has been in business for 3 years. He is from Uromi, Edo State. He needs the loan amount of $700 to buy computers and a photocopier. He said this will help him serve his customers better.

loans.use: To buy a system unit and photocopier

loans.name: La Amistad Group

texts.es:
The Amistad (Friendship) Association has been part of the family of Pro-Mujer (Pro-woman) for several years, complying with the terms of the previous 19 rounds of financing. The association is based in Alto Lima area, city of El Alto. Currently, it has 15 members and has proved to be a well-organized group on account of their loan repayment track record.

Most members of the association are married with children, almost all of whom are of school age. A few of the children have been unable to attend school due to their families’ lack of resources, the need to assist their parents in running their small businesses, and caring for their younger siblings. Association members are engaged in a variety of activities such as sale of meat, dairy products, and under-garments. Their main activity, however, is production of sportswear, which they sell at fairs in La Paz.

They believe they need additional capital to purchase better quality fabrics for the production of higher quality sportswear to attract more customers and increase their profits. Their sole aim is to improve their standard of living so that they can provide their children with better opportunities in life, particularly in the area of education.

Translated from Spanish by MuseAndThinker, Kiva Volunteer

La asociación denominada “la amistad” pertenece a la familia de pro-mujer hace ya varios años cumpliendo con 19 ciclos de crédito, esta se encuentra en la zona de alto lima, de la ciudad de el alto, a la fecha cuenta con 15 socias y ha demostrado ser un grupo organizado en cuanto a sus cuotas de crédito. Dentro el grupo la mayoría son casadas y con hijos, casi todos en edad escolar, existiendo algunos casos que por falta de recursos lastimosamente sus hijos no pudieron ingresar a la escuela. ya que estos deben ayudar a sus padres en sus pequeños negocios y cuidar de sus hermanos menores. Existen diferentes negocios dentro la asociación como ser; la venta de carne de pollo, de lácteos, ropa intima pero la actividad principal es la costura de prendas deportivas que una vez producidas las venden en las ferias de la ciudad de la paz ellas afirman que necesitan mayor capital para la compra de telas de mejor calidad de esta manera sus productos también tendrían mejor calidad y así obtendrían mayores clientes y por consiguiente mayores ganancias con el unico objetivo de mejorar su situación económica de esta manera ofrecer a sus hijos una mejor forma de vida principalmente en su educación.

loans.use: Additional capital for the purchase of better quality materials and fabrics

loans.name: Believe In God Group

texts.en:
Aminata K. is very grateful to Kiva for her previous loan of $175. Because of that loan, Aminata can now purchase two baskets of dried fish at the same time and has increased her profit and capital. With the profit, Aminata purchased land to build a house for her family.

Aminata is a group leader. She and the other two members, Fatu I. and Marie T., have developed their savings and rotating club. They save some amount weekly to repay their installments.

Fatu and Marie are also engaged in fish selling. All the members would like to expand their business.

loans.use: To purchase a stock of dried fish.

loans.name: Mujeres Trabajadoras De Tobatí Group

texts.es:
This committee is formed by 15 hard-working women from the San Blas neighborhood in the city of Tobatí. The group is currently in the third cycle of the Mujeres Emprendedoras (Entrepreneurial Women) program, and to date, they all manage a line of credit of approximately 667.000 guaranis per member.

The committee was formed after Rosa Gómez, acting president of the committee, learned of the program through her brother who is a client of Fundación Paraguaya. In no time, Rosa gathered the 15 women, which is the minimum required to form a committee, and thereafter started the training cycle. Today, they tell us they are very happy to be part of an organization whose goal is the development of humble and hard-working people, and of course, even more satisfied for the fact that their committee is formed by their own neighbors.

The loans they receive will be invested in the purchase of ingredients necessary for the elaboration of chipas (typical dish from Paraguay) such as starch, oil and cheese, as well as herbs, sugar, sodas, meat and noodles. Those that sell clothing will purchase used clothing wholesale, which will allow them to acquire it a lower price.

The committee’s objective for the month of June is to hold typical dish fairs to raise funds for their savings, being that the celebrations in honor of San Juan are in proximity and in which dishes such as mbeyú (starch tortilla with cheese), madi´o (yucca turnover) and other dishes are commonly consumed.

Translated from Spanish by Evelyn Garcia, Kiva Volunteer.

El comité está integrado por 15 señoras trabajadoras del barrio San Blas de la ciudad de Tobatí, el grupo se encuentra actualmente en el 3er. Ciclo del programa Mujeres Emprededoras, y a la fecha todas manejan una línea de crédito promedio de gs. 667.000 por cada integrantes.

El comité fue formado gracias a que la señora Rosa Gómez, actual presidenta del comité, tuvo conocimiento del programa a través de su hermano quien es cliente de la Fundación Paraguaya. La señora Rosa en poco tiempo llegó a juntar las 15 señoras, que es el mínimo del requisito exigido para formar el comité y así se inicio el ciclo de capacitación, hoy día manifiestan que están muy contentas de ser parte de una organización que tiene como finalidad el crecimiento de la gente humilde y trabajadora y por su puesto mucho mas satisfecha por el hecho de que la misma están conformadas por sus propias vecinas.

Los préstamos que recibirán lo invertirán en la compra de productos para la elaboración de chipas (comida típica del Paraguay) como ser almidón, aceite, queso, como así también para la compra de yerba, azúcar, gaseosas, carne, fideo, gaseosas, las que se dedican a la venta de ropa, compraron ropas usadas en forma mayorista esto le permitió obtener un precio mas bajo.

El comité tiene como objetivo este mes de junio la de realizar ferias de comidas típicas para recaudar fondos para sus ahorros, considerando que se aproxima las fiestas de San Juan, dónde es muy común el consumo de estos tipos de comidas como el mbeyú (tortilla de almidón con queso), pastel madi´o (empanada de mandioca), entre otros.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise such as sugar, herbs, starch, vegetable oil, cheese, milk, cookies, beef, sodas, beer and other types of beverages as well as men's, women's and children's clothing.

loans.name: Top-Up Group

texts.en:
Pictured are Osman C., Unisa K., Mummy G. and Hawa S.. Their group is called Top-up, named after the main product the group leader is selling. They have finished repaying their previous loan with SMT. That loan helped their businesses grow, increased profit and improved on the members living conditions. Another loan of Le 4,000,000 loan will help give strength to their businesses.

The leader of this group is Osman C.. Osman is 35 and was born in Yele, Tonkolili district. He is married with 2 children. Osman owes a tele-centre. Here, he makes telephone calls for people, sells top-up cards, phone batteries, recharges mobile phones (as 95% of the people do not have electricity, people pay Le 1,000.00 for their phones to be recharged) and so on. Other members of the group also sell top-ups, cigarettes, mints, candles, biscuits, under-wears, bras, childrens` clothes, fish and so on.

loans.use: Expand on their current businesses.

loans.name: Muhabbathon

texts.ru:
Алимбаева Мухаббатхон 1961 года рождения, разведенная, имеет 3 детей.  У нее высшее образование и 10 лет опыта в сфере продаж женской одежды и обуви. Местом деятельности Мухаббатхон является торговый центр «Садбарг» города Душанбе.  Свои товары в основном закупает из поставщиков с Китая и Турции. 
Мухаббатхон имеет своих постоянных клиентов. В ассортименте ее товара можно найти обувь и одежду на любой вкус. Ее девиз «Клиент – всегда прав»! Учитываю этот девиз она старается  угождать своим клиентом разновидностью ассортиментов своих товаров.
Услышав о программе Кива, она захотела участвовать и в сезон осенней обуви расширить наименование товаров, увеличив товарооборот. Мухаббатхон хочет  получить займ в сумме 4100 сомони сроком на 10 месяцев.
texts.en:
Muhabbathon A. was born in 1961. She is divorced and has three children. She has a higher education and 10 years of experience selling women's clothing and shoes. She works out of the trade center "Sadbarg" in Dushanbe City. She purchases her products primarily from suppliers in China and Turkey. Muhabbathon has her regular clients. Her supply includes all kinds of styles of shoes and clothing. Her motto is "the client is always right" and she tries to provide her clients with a varied assortment of goods. Having heard about Kiva's programs, she wanted to participate and for the autumn season would like to expand her line of goods and increase her turnover. She would like to take out a loan in the amount of 4100 somoni for 10 months.

Translated from Russian by Josh Machleder, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Expansion of product line

loans.name: Rosa Isela

texts.es:
Rosa Isela inició el negocio por las ganas de convertirse en una persona independiente, capaz de ganar su propio dinero con esfuerzo y dedicación y no tener que depender siempre de lo que le obsequia su esposo sino poder comprar sus propias cosas y comprarles a sus hijos. Comenzó su negocio hace como 5 años, aproximadamente en Febrero del 2003, gracias a un inquilino que tuvo, al que le rentaba el departamento donde vivía, el era agente de ventas, el la animo a que se dedicar a las ventas por que veía que podría llegar a ser una persona exitosa en este negocio. Lo platico con su esposo y el la apoyó, incluso la financió para que ella pudiera comprar su primer mercancía (ropa) con la incertidumbre de no saber como le iría, pero le fue muy bien y ahora ya tiene muchos clientes

Ella necesita un préstamo por US $375 que pagara en 4 meses para poder surtir ropa y artesanías que le permitan atender mejor las necesidades de sus clientes y así sus ventas puedan aumentar considerablemente. Con tu apoyo esto será posible.
texts.en:
Rosa Isela started the business with the desire to become an independent person capable of earning her own money with effort and dedication, not always having to depend on what her husband can provide but but being able to buy her own things and buy things for their children. She started her business 5 years ago, around February of 2003, thanks to a tenant who was the agent of sales for the apartment they were renting and he inspired her to dedicate herself to sales because he saw that she could become a successful person in this business. She talked with her husband and he supported her decision, even funding it so that she could buy her first merchandise (clothing), uncertain of how it would go, but it went very well and now she has many customers.

She needs a loan of US $ 375 to pay in 4 months to produce clothing and crafts to enable her to better meet the needs of her customers and which could cause her sales to increase significantly. With your support this will be possible.

Translated from Spanish by Helen Smith, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Produce merchandise

loans.name: Gerardo

texts.es:
Gerardo inició el negocio por ser un oficio que aprendió desde joven ya que el deseaba tener un empleo y aprender un oficio ya que no pudo continuar con sus estudios debido a razones económicas, es por esto que hace 14 años comenzó de ayudante de albañil y ahora es maestro albañil por lo que el realiza contratos en donde puedo tener mas utilidad y ofrecerles mejor calidad de vida a sus tres pequeños hijos de 5, 3 y 1 año.

El necesita un préstamo por US $400 que pagara en 6 meses para comprar herramienta que requiere en su trabajo diario. Con tu apoyo Gerardo saldrá adelante.
texts.en:
Gerardo began his business because this is a trade that he learned when he was young. He desired to have a job and learn a trade, because he could not continue with his studies due to economic reasons. This is why fourteen years ago he began as a masonry apprentice and now he is a master mason. He does his own contracts now so he can offer a better quality of life to his three little children, who are one, three, and five years old. He needs a loan for $400, which he will pay back in six months, to buy tools that he requires in his daily jobs. With your support Gerardo will come out on top.

Translated from Spanish by Jay Osborne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buy tools

loans.name: Ekah

texts.en:
Ekah A. has a business selling fuel. Purchasing kerosene and cooking gases is very expensive, so many people resort to using firewood for cooking. Ekah sells firewood and palm oil to those people. She makes the most in sales from her firewood business.

She is now requesting a loan of N120,000 so she can purchase more firewood to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more firewood to sell

loans.name: Ama

texts.en:
Ama S., a 35-year-old trader, is married with three kids. All of them are currently in school. She trades in cereals like maize, beans, tubers of yam, and rice on top of a table in the local market of Abeka in Accra. She requests the loan to enable her buy increased stock of maize and rice to grow her business and scale up sales. Ama has being in this business for the past 2 years without any regret for what she does. She says her major challenge has to do with the kids’ school fees. She hopes to increase her savings to support the children education to give them better future career opportunities. Ama said she lives because of them.

She belongs to the community group called Boldness Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral and assist one another to repay the loan. She does not sell on group meeting days and her picture was taken during her group meeting.

loans.use: To buy more maize and rice.

loans.name: Faafetai

texts.en:
Faafetai U., 44, is married with three children.  She has many years of experience in the elei printing materials business.  She sells to the general public and villagers three days per week.  She expects her weekly net cash flows to be 400 Tala (~166 USD).  

She has two previous loans with SPBD.  SPBD loans are Faafetai’s only access to capital because she was unable to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.  Part of this loan will be used for building a small house for business purposes only.

loans.use: Purchase buying paintings, brushes, stencils, carving woods and materials.

loans.name: Sona

texts.fr: Sona  B. est une jeune femme qui mène ses petites activités en vendant de la glace. Elle dispose d'un réfrigérateur et chaque soir elle y met une quarantaine de sachets de  d'un litre d'eau en vue de leur congélation au bout de vingt heures environ. La boulangerie du coin est abonnée chez elle pour la fourniture journalière de vingt-cinq glaces. C'est par cette activité que Sona parvient à subvenir à ses besoins et à épargner petit à petit. Elle voudrait ainsi l’extension de  son activité afin de pouvoir assurer une distribution plus large, ceci par l'acquisition d'un deuxième réfrigérateur
texts.en:
Sona B. is a young woman who runs a small business selling ice. She has a refrigerator into which, every evening, she puts some 40 one-liter bags of water, which freeze in about 20 hours. The corner bakery is a customer of hers, to whom she supplies 25 blocks of ice each day. It is through this business activity that Sona is able to support herself and make small savings. She would like to grow her business and distribute her ice more extensively. For this she needs a second refrigerator.

Translated from French by Alison Dent, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To make and sell ice

loans.name: Binodira

texts.en:
Education is the most important inheritance Binodira and her husband can give to their five dear children.  They are both very responsible parents and they work very hard in agriculture and farming so that they can give their children the opportunity to finish school – an opportunity they never had due to poor finances. 

This happy mother has been working in agriculture since getting married and, with the unconditional help of her husband, she buys and sells cattle in order to cover the family’s most urgent needs.  Even so, she now finds herself with more expenditures and she would like a loan in order to increase their capital by increasing their production. 

Binodira and her family are waiting for your quick response. 


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road, the end of Alexander the Great's rule, and it’s famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets such as Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others.  

The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC.  And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. 

But, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics.  The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy.  In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable.  These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia.  

While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. 

IMON's History
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition.  Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need.  To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit www.imon.tj.

loans.use: Purchasing cattle and small cattle to expand the business.

loans.name: Anita

texts.es:
La señora Anita, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Picota”, vive en la Av. Fernando B. Terry 3 Cdra., Distrito de Picota, Departamento de San Martín. Es soltera, tiene 50 años y es madre 7 hijos, 2 que todavía dependen de ella.

Se inicio con  S/. 300.00 por iniciativa propia, empezó con la venta de comida, atendiendo en su misma casa. Tiene 02 años trabajando con el Banco.

En la actualidad, continua con el mismo negocio de venta de comida en su restaurant y en las noches vende pollos a la brasa, siendo sus principales clientes  los moradores de la comunidad, vecinos y amigos.

Con el último préstamo de S/1,200.00 que cancelara a plazo de 06 meses, desea invertirlo comprando insumos para la preparación diaria de sus alimentos como sacos de arroz, azúcar; pollos desviscerados, papas, salsa de tomates, mostaza, todo esto para la venta de pollos a la brasa por las noches y también  mesas, sillas, vasos y ollas, para implementar su negocio. 

Ella toma las decisiones en las ganancias de su negocio. Hoy se siente una Mujer independiente, más responsable con el pago de sus cuotas.

Anita, manifiesta su agradecimiento a Manuela Ramos por permitirle crecer como Mujer y Empresaria.
texts.en:
Anita belongs to the community bank "Picota" and lives at Av. Fernando B, Terry 3 block, Picota district, San Martin state. She is single, 50 years old, and a mother of 7 children, 2 of whom she still supports. With an initial loan of S/ 300, she started selling foods made out of her home. She has been working with the bank for 2 years. Currently, she continues with the same business of food sales from her restaurant and she sells grilled chickens at night. Her main customers are people from her community, neighbors, and friends. With this loan of S/ 1,200, to be paid in 6 monthly installments, she would like to invest in the purchase of daily food prepartion items such as rice, sugar, chicken, potatoes, tomatoes, mustard, and everything that she needs to sell grilled chicken at night which includes tables, chairs, glasses, and pans in order to establish the business. She makes her decisions based on what is profitable for her business. Today she feels like an independent woman, more responsible with her monthly payments. Anita would like to express her gratitude to Manuela Ramos for allowing her to grow as a woman and entrepreneur.

Translated from Spanish by Brittany Thatcher, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase preparation items for the sale of food.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace I. is currently in the business of selling maize flour at the market and is requesting a loan to buy more flour and other food items to sell. Grace is 52 years old and is widowed. She has 5 children, and her children do not go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a permanent house for settlement.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.

BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: buy more four and other food items to sell

loans.name: Faavae

texts.en:
Faavae C. L., 36, is married with two children. She has two years of experience in the canteen business. She sells to the general public five days per week. She has had one previous loan with SPBD, a Kiva partner.

She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 450 Tala (about $187). SPBD loans are Faavae’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase sugar, flour, oil, foam cups, cordial

loans.name: Deo

texts.en: Deo L. is a married Tanzanian man who runs a small business. He has a hardware shop where he sells a variety of items to customers. His business is in the Yombo Vituka ward in Dar es Salaam. He purchases the business goods from wholesale and retail shops and sells on a retail basis to customers. His business plan is to run a wholesale hardware shop once he gets enough funds. He has been in the business for six years. He needs a loan of Tshs 1,400,000 to boost up the business.

loans.use: To boost up the business by purchasing more business goods

loans.name: Angelina

texts.en:
Angelina S. is engaged in a charcoal-vending business. Aside from her charcoal selling, she also maintains a hog-raising business. Her husband manages a motorcycle transport in their village.

Angelina is requesting to borrow PHP 5,000 in order to maintain her businesses and be able to generate higher income for her children who are all studying at the moment. Her two children are Crescene Joy and Langon.

The couple works together to make their businesses successful and to increase their family’s standard of living. Currently, Agelina and her family are happily living in the mountainous village of Liwayway Diffun, Quirino Province.

loans.use: To maintain her businesses and generate higher income

loans.name: Cayetana

texts.es:
La señora Cayetana, pertenece al Banco Comunal “San Juan D. Dios”, ubicado en el distrito D. Lampa, Provincia D. San Román, Departamento D. Puno. Tiene 49 años D. edad, es casada, es madre D. 5 hijos y 4 D. ellos a su cargo, tiene estudios D. primaria completa. Vive en el Barrio Nueva Esperanza en el Jr. Municipalidad s/n en Lampa.

Trabaja con el movimiento Manuela Ramos hace 2 años, inicio su trabajo con un prestamos D. S/. 300.00, con el cual compró carne, víveres en general para distribuirlo a las ferias.

Actualmente solicita un préstamo D. S/. 700.00, el cual le permitirá incrementar su negocio comprando productos D. la zona como: papa, quinua y frutas como: plátanos, naranjas y otros. 

Su mayor sueño es darle una profesión a cada uno D. sus hijos.

A ella le gustan las reuniones que hace su Banco Comunal ya que le enseñan a ahorrar.
texts.en:
Mrs. Cayetana belongs to the San Juan of God Community Bank located in the Lampa District, in San Roman Province, Department of Puno. She is 49 years old, married, and mother of five children, four of whom have completed their primary school studies. She lives in Barrio Nueva Esperanza (Community of New Hope). She has worked with the Manuela Ramos movement for two years. She began her work with a loan of S/. 300, with which she bought meat and general provisions to sell at the local markets. She now requests a loan of S/. 700 which will permit her to increase her business, buying products from the area such as potatoes, quinoa, and fruits such as bananas, oranges, and others. Her greatest dream is to proviD. an occupation for each of her children. She likes the meetings that her Community Bank holds since they teach her to save.

Translated from Spanish by Daniel Burke, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: She will buy potatoes, quinua, bananas, oranges, and other fruits.

loans.name: Thomas

texts.en: Thomas is a 41-year-old trader. He is married with no children. He is a very resourceful man whose hard efforts brings livelihood to the family. He supports his family through the sale of used clothing. Selling of used clothing has a very big market share in Ghana. Brand new clothes are very expensive for the economically active poor. Therefore selling of used clothing has created market for many Ghanaians. Thomas has been in this business for the past 26 years. He travels to a nearby city, called Kumasi, to purchase his stock of goods. He wants to use the loan to buy more bales of used clothing to increase his inventory. He believes this loan will help him save for the future.

loans.use: To buy increased bales of used clothing.

loans.name: Sajama 1 Group

texts.en:
The members of Sajama named their group after the part of town where they live, which is characterized by single-story adobe homes. Since these women all live in the same part of town, they know each other pretty well. They are excited to be taking out their very first loan and are looking forward to the growth of their businesses over the next few months. 

The board members of this group are strong and responsible leaders who make sure that their members come to meetings on time, make all of their payments, and work well together. 

The majority of the members in this group work in the clothing sector; they sew and knit shawls and jackets from sheep and llama wool, and they buy and sell commercial clothing. Other members sell bread, cake, cheese, chicken, vegetables, and gift items.

They need a loan to buy more materials like cloth, wool and yarn to make clothing, and also to buy more commercial products to sell at their stands. With more inventory, it will be much easier for these women to attract clients, and the higher profits will enable them to make their lives better.

loans.use: To buy material for production and to buy products to sell

loans.name: Mrs. Phan Surn Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Phan S. is the group leader of a six-member group, all of whom are living in Sam Raong village in Takeo province.

Mrs. Phan S. is 43 years old and the mother of three children who are all attending the local school. Her husband, Mr. P. Thean, is a palm-juice collector who gathers palm juice to process into palm sugar.

Mrs. Phan S. is a farmer who owns a small piece of land on which she cultivates rice to earn a living. She now faces a small problem with infertile soil and so she decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer to support the field to make her crop more productive. She would use the rest of the loan to buy piglets to raise.

All the people in this group loan have end-of-term (EoT) loans so they are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. EoT loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for her rice field and to buy piglets to raise

loans.name: Varvara

texts.en:
Varvara is married with a grown daughter. She is an entrepreneur from Zaporozhye where she works in the local market called Angolenko. She sells women’s outerwear and has already gained loyal clientele thanks to the variety of merchandise she has for sale and affordable prices.

Varvara has been running this business for fifteen years. Presently, she has 30,000 Grivnyas in turnover capital and about 3,000 Grivnyas in net profit every month.

Varvara is seeking a loan of 13,800 Grivnyas to purchase additional seasonal merchandise. All the loans she received prior to the current loan have had a big impact on her business and she is excited to be able to use additional funding to increase her sales even further.

This available capital will give Varvara the resources and flexibility to buy inventory in greater volume, allowing her to have more time and energy to focus on expanding her business.

loans.use: To purchase seasonal clothing

loans.name: Gloria

texts.es: LA SEÑORA GLORIA SE DEDICA A LA VENTA DE MUEBLES DE MADERA DESDE HACE UN AÑO Y MEDIO, ES SOLTERA, ESTA EN UNA ZONA DONDE SE VENDE SOLO MUEBLES. TRAE DESDE LA CIUDAD DE LA PAZ, SU TIENDA ESTA EN ALQUILER. ES CLIENTE DE CREDITO INDIVIDUAL DONDE NO TIENE NINGUN ATRASO, ES UNA SOCIA RESPONSABLE Y DEDICADA A SU NEGOCIO, ELLA TIENE UN SOLO HIJO, ESTA SEPARADA  DEL ESPOSO Y DESDE ESE MOMENTO SE DEDICO A TENER ESE NEGOCIO PARA PODER APOYAR A SU HIJO.
texts.en:
Sra. Gloria has been selling wood furniture for 1½ years. She is single and lives in an area of town where only furniture is sold. The furniture is shipped in from the city of La Paz to her store, which is in a rented location.

Gloria is receiving an individual loan and she has not had any previous delays. She is a responsible member who is dedicated to her business. She has one child and is separated from her husband. At the moment, she focuses on her business so that she can support her child.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase a variety of furniture for resale

loans.name: Sapoben Ii Group

texts.en:
Here are members of the Sapoben II group. Members of the this group are small-scale businesspeople in the town of Magburaka, in the Tonkolili district, northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan from SMT/Kiva for the first time. Each is requesting a loan of Le 500,000 to improve his/her business, consequently improving his/her standard of living.

Abdul T. K. (second from left) is the leader of this group. Abdul was born in Magburaka town about thirty-six years ago. He is married to a businesswoman and they have four children. Three of Abdul’s children are attending primary schools and the other is in nursery school. Abdul sells used clothing. He has been in this business since 1992.

loans.use: Invest in his business

loans.name: Susan

texts.en: Susan A. is from the village of Calawag, Barangay Pugaan, Iligan City. She is 43 years old, is married, and has nine school-aged children. Susan owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling a variety of basic-need products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month. In October 2009, Susan joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering

location.town: Calawag, Puga-an, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Martha

texts.es: La señora Martha Sánchez de 39 años de edad, casada vive en Waspan Norte en la capital de Managua, procreo  dos hijos  de 15 y 18 años de edad,  uno estudia y el otro trabaja para poder ayudar a su mama con los gastos, el esposo de doña Martha es mecánico pero su salario es bajo y cuando  no hay mucho trabajo gana menos, sus planes es poder seguirle haciendo las mejoras a su vivienda, ella trabaja como enfermera  en un centro de salud, donde ayuda  a mucha gente enferma, del dengue que es el mas común por los mosquitos, ya que se da muchos en los barrios por que no hay aguas negra, las calles son de tierra entre otros, con este préstamo hará el baño de su casa para tener una mejor higiene y comodidad para el aseo personal de su familia, es su quinto ciclo en la institución y esta sastifecha por que ha logrado hacer mejoras a su casa
texts.en:
Mrs. Martha Sánchez is 39 years old and lives in the North Waspan neighborhood of the Nicaraguan capital city of Managua. She has two children who are 15 and 18 years old; one is in school and the other works to help his mother pay for household expenses. Martha's husband is a mechanic, but his salary is very low and when there isn't much work he earns even less. Her plans are to continue making improvements to their home. Martha works as a nurse at a health center, where she helps many people who are sick with dengue, the most common illness caused by mosquitoes. Dengue is very common in local neighborhoods, where the streets are unpaved, because of the contaminated water supply. With this loan, Martha will install a bathroom in her home in order to provide her family with improved hygiene and comfort. This is her fifth loan cycle with the institution, and she is pleased that she has been able to make home improvements.

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy construction materials to build a bathroom so that her family will have a more comfortable, hygienic environment

loans.name: Consolacion

texts.en:
Consolacion A. is married and blessed with four children, who are all students. They live in the village of Cabaruan, Naguilian, Isabela. Consolacion's husband works on the farm, while she manages a hog-raising business. They dream that their children will finish their college education.

Consolacion wants to improve her business. In order to pursue her plans, she is requesting a loan of 6,000 Philippine pesos (PHP), which she will use to buy additional piglets to raise.

In her one year in this business, she has already had profits. The additional income was quite helpful in meeting her family’s needs. She wants to improve her income so that she can better provide for the needs of her family.

loans.use: To buy additional hogs to raise.

loans.name: Rosario

texts.en:
Rosario S. is from the village of Balanlinao, Plaridel, Misamis Occidental. She is 53 years old. Rosario is married and has three adult children. To make a living, Rosario owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for sale. Rosario has been engaged in her business for more than two years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Rosario joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosario is requesting a new loan of 3,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers and feed. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Rosario from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and feed

loans.name: Olga Marina

texts.es:
Olga Marina es una mujer activa y trabajadora, vive en el distrito de Campo Verde, región de Ucayali. Ella tiene 44 años, es madre de tres hijos(dos mayores de edad) y cuenta con el apoyo de su esposo quien es agricultor.
Maria se dedica diariamente a la venta de tamales, empanadas y humitas.
Forma parte del Banco Comunal “Las Nazarenas” desde hace cuatro años y el primer crédito que recibió fue de 300.00 nuevos soles con los que pudo comprar productos para la preparación de sus alimentos.
Actualmente necesita un crédito de 800.00 nuevos soles con los que comprarà fuentes, mesas, sillas y manteles. 
La meta de Olga Marina es tener un una fuente de soda y su propio local.
texts.en:
Olga Marina is an active and hard-working woman who lives in the Campo Verde district in the region of Ucayali. She is 44 years old, has three children (two of whom are grown-up) and she lives with her husband who is a farmer. Maria sells tamales (a regional dish comprised of dough steamed in either corn or banana leaves), empanadas (stuffed pastries), and humitas (corn paste wrapped in corn leaves). She has been part of the Communal Bank “Las Nazarenas” for four years and her first loan was for 300.00 new soles, which she used to buy the necessary ingredients for her food. She now needs a loan of 800.00 new soles to buy serving dishes, tables, chairs, and tablecloths. Olga Marina's goal is to set up a soda fountain and to own her space.

Translated from Spanish by Julia Kastner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: She needs a loan to buy serving dishes, tables, chairs, and tablecloths.

loans.name: Elsy

texts.es:
Elsy tiene 40 años, vive con su esposo Basilio, quien viaja constantemente, y con sus 2 hijos: Larry (17) y Sara (8), todos ellos viven en su casa propia.
Desde hace 7 años ella se dedica a la venta de comestibles en la tienda - bazar que posee en su propio domicilio. Esta actividad  le permite brindarle a su familia un futuro mejor, ya que con el sueldo de su esposo no se dan abasto para todos los gastos. Elsy empieza su jornada diaria a las 7 de la mañana y se prolonga hasta promediarse las 8 de la noche; la venta es muy buena, ya que Elsy es muy carismática y siempre atiende muy bien a sus clientes, es por ello que se ha hecho de muy buenos amigos en su vecindario.
Gracias a los préstamos que anteriormente solicitó en MFP ha logrado implementar en una parte de su tienda un mini bazar donde ofrece productos de belleza y algunos artículos de decoración y uso personal. 

Elsy quiere seguir creciendo y es por ello que recurre a otro préstamo con MFP, siendo este su 18avo crédito, y en todos estos años (8), siempre ha demostrado mucha responsabilidad en sus pagos. Con el dinero que ahora solicita comprará mayor cantidad de mercadería para su bazar, ya que sabe habrá mucha demanda por fiestas de fin de año.
texts.en:
Elsy, 40, lives with her husband Basilio, who travels constantly, and their two children, Larry, 17, and Sara, 8. They all live together and have their own house. Seven years ago, Elsy started a business selling food products in the shop she has in her house. This allowed her to provide a better future for her children, as her husband’s income is not sufficient to meet their expenses. Elsy begins her work each day at 7AM and usually works until about 8PM. Sales are good, as Elsy is very charismatic and is attentive to the needs of her customers. Because of this, she has many friends in the community. Thanks to previous loans with MFP, she has converted part of her house into a mini-store where she offers beauty products and a few decorative articles and personal accessories. Elsy wants to keep expanding her business, so she is asking for her this, her 18th loan with MFP. Over these eight years, she has been very responsible in her payments. With this loan, she will buy more merchandise for her store, as she knows there is much demand for the New Year festivities.

Translated from Spanish by jeffrey hersk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Merchandise for store

loans.name: Kom

texts.en:
Kom K., 51, is married and lives with her two school-aged children in Kompongcham Province, Cambodia. K. has a business of selling various kinds of groceries. She is able to earn an income of $15 per day to help cover the family expenses. She has been in this business since 2005. Her husband is a veterinarian in their village. He always provides regular health care to animals in the village and he is able to earn an income of $8 per day to assist his family.  

K. and her family members try to work hard and help each other to ensure a good standard of living for the family. They are seeking to improve their businesses as well. As a result, K. is requesting a loan of $500 from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner. She wants to use the loan to purchase piglets to raise for sale when they are sufficiently big enough. This is her first loan from CREDIT.

loans.use: To buy pigs to raise for sale

loans.name: Sarai Group

texts.es:
El grupo Sarai está integrado por cuatro mujeres trabajadoras una de ellas es  María José Gomez quien es la coordinadora del grupo. Está señora de 32 años inicio vendiendo gaseosa pero ella necesitaba un negocio que le brindara mayores ganancias es así que gracias a los créditos empieza a comercializar cosméticos y accesorios.

Las otras integrantes del grupo son Melba del Socorro B. quien vende helados, frescos y hielo, María Aydee M. vende gaseosas, frescos y comida los fines de semana y María Inecilia Elizabebeth S. tiene una pulperia.
texts.en:
The Sarai group is made up of four hard-working women. One of them is María José Gomez, 32, who is the group coordinator. She started out selling soft-drinks but she needed a business that produced higher profits. Thanks to the financing she was able to go into cosmetics and accessories sales. The other members of the group are: Melba del Socorro B., who sells frozen treats, ice and frescos (smoothie-like fruit drink), María Aydee M., who sells soft-drinks, frescos and prepared food on the weekend, and María Inecilia Elizabebeth S., who has a grocery store.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cosmetics and accessories.

loans.name: Maria Angelita

texts.es:
Maria Angelita tiene 22 años de edad, es casada y vive junto a su esposo y a su menor hijo en el caserío Chepito Alto del distrito de Mórrope, ubicado a 45 minutos de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Se dedica a la venta de combustible en su domicilio desde hace un año. Ella nos comenta que la iniciativa de su negocio nació debido a la falta de agua para regar los sembríos de la zona. Los agricultores han hecho pozos y riegan con ellos sus cultivos, pero para realizar esta a cción deben utilizar motores, los cuales necesitan de gasolina para funcionar.

Este negocio le brinda ingresos adicionales que son de mucha ayuda para el sostenimiento de su familia ya que su esposo, al igual que la mayoría de hombres de a zona, trabaja como obrero agrícola y lo que percibe no le basta para sustentar la economía familiar.

Maria Angelita desea ampliar su negocio con la compra de más combustible y aceite, con los cuales pueda seguir atendiendo la demanda de su producto. Por ello se encuentra solicitando por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1000 nuevos soles que piensa utilizar en el logro de su objetivo.

Ella es una joven madre trabajadora, responsable y muy entregada a su familia. Su mayor anhelo es brindarle a su familia una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Maria Angelita is 22 years old. She is married and lives with her husband and their minor child in the small town Chepito Alto of the district of Mórrope, located 45 minutes from the city of Chiclayo. She has been selling fuel from her house for more than a year. She tells us that the idea for her business was born from the lack of water to irrigate the plantings in the area. The farmers have made wells and they irrigate their crops with them. In order to do this, they have to use motors, which need gasoline to work. This business has brought her additional income which are a big help for the family's support. Her husband, like most of the men in the area, works as an agricultural laborer and what he makes is not enough to support the family economy. Maria Angelita wishes to grow her business with the purchase of more fuel and oil, with which she can continue to attend to the demand for her product. Due to this she is asking Edpyme Alternativa for the first time for a loan of 1000 nuevos soles. She plans on using it to acheive her goal. She is a young, hardworking mother and very dedicated to her family. Her biggest wish is to give her family a better quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Ellen Donohue, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase gasoline and oil to grow her business.

loans.name: Fady

texts.en:
Fady is a 52 year old man who lives in the Beirut, capital of Lebanon with his wife and their two children. Fady has been working as carpenter since 1994. He requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase wood for his work. This is the first time that Fady has requested a loan.

He is special in his work because he does a good and precise work. His clients are his friends and neighbors. When he first started his business, he had to face the competition and some financial issues due to the war in Lebanon. He decided on doing his business because he wanted to have an independent work as well as from his experience and he likes his work

loans.use: To purchase wood for his work

loans.name: Tupendane A Group

texts.en:
Zainabu H., age 53, is married with grown up kids.  She has a food vendor business, which she started in 2004.  She works from 5:30AM to 12:00PM daily, and she is able to make monthly profits of about $114.

This will be Zainabu’s tenth loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She used the previous loans to start the business of darks and increase her food business volume.  She has paid back the loans successfully.  She hopes for a new loan to continue improving the stock and quality of her food, and to start selling fabrics and liquid soap.

Zainabu will share this loan with her subgroup, Tupendane A Group, which totals 5 members.  The members of the group will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan. 

In the picture, Zainabu is in a green and yellow dress.

loans.use: To improve stock and quality food, and start selling fabrics and liquid soap

loans.name: Chinbat

texts.en: Chinbat is 36 years old and lives with his wife and three children in Zavhan province, Mongolia. He and his family live together in a house that they own. They have been living together in their current home for 13 years. Currently, Chinbat operates a juniper trading business with his wife. Juniper is an important part of spiritual cleansing in Buddhism. He has been operating his business since 1998 and has steadily expanded his business since that time. He has also built a good reputation among his customers. His business is very popular and his customer base includes both residents of his province as well as other provinces. Presently, he made a contract to supply juniper to a new monastery that recently opened in the Selenge province. He has been planning to build his own workplace on his own plot of land. Chinbat is a very energetic person and says, “I am working hard to build a bright future for my family.” He is requesting a 3,000,000-tugrug loan to purchase necessary equipment for his business.

loans.use: To purchase tools

loans.name: Juan Pablo

texts.es:
El señor Pablo D. esta muy agradecido por su cooperación en el anterior crédito el cual pudo obtener su vivienda. 
A su casa le esta haciendo falta algunos detalles pero el quiere empezar con los acabados del exterior, ya que cuando llueve hay mucha humedad en la casa y sus pequeños hijos se le enferman. 
Esta solicitando su cooperación nuevamente en este crédito y planea pagarlo con una parte de las ganancias que obtiene de su negocio de pintor de carros, ya que es la fuente de ingresos de su familia. 
La persona que aparece en la foto es la señora Maria Esther Ortiz esposa del señor Juan Pablo D. ya que el se encontraba en su taller, cuando se realizo la visita.
texts.en:
Sr. Pablo Diaz is very grateful for the assistance from his previous loan, which he used to obtain his home. His home is lacking a few details, so he wants to begin with the exterior finishes. When it rains, it becomes very humid inside his house and his young children become sick. He is requesting your cooperation with another loan which he plans to repay using part of his earnings from his business painting cars. This is his family’s source of income. The person in the photo is Sra. Maria Esther Ortiz, Sr. Juan Pablo Diaz's wife. Juan Pablo Diaz was not available for the photo since he works during the day at his shop.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Finish the exterior of his house

loans.name: Safia's Group

texts.en:
Safia is a wife of M. A. and belongs to a city named Borewala (city famous for its shrines) in Pakistan. She owns a small house of two rooms and has been living in it with her family for the past 8 years. Safia is an uneducated lady but she doesn’t want to befall the same destiny for her children. 

She has six children: five sons and one daughter. Her first three sons completed their education up to the 8th standard and couldn’t get study further because the state of their house was getting worse, day by day, and they needed to generate income. They decided to quit their studies. Her elder two work in a local factory on monthly wages. The next son is a daily wage laborer in the wooden market. Now, with the income, they are helping their younger siblings to achieve their education. Their two younger brothers read in 2nd standard and their sister reads in 3rd standard.

Safia is also a very hardworking lady. She prepares embroidered dresses by receiving the orders from her neighbors and thereby earns income. She saves her income for her children's good futures. She has a wish that her financial condition will improve so that her elder sons also can continue their education. Her husband is a fruit vendor. He sells fruit by going to different areas of the community on his four-wheeled cart. He has been doing this work for over 10 years. 

Safia has successfully repaid her three previous loans to Asasah (microfinance institute in Pakistan and a partner of Kiva) and is now applying for a loan for the fourth time to purchase seasonal fruits, in bulk, so that her husband may expand his business and increase the profit.

loans.use: To purchase seasonal fruits in bulk to sell.

loans.name: Orly

texts.en:
Orly R. is from the village of Francfort, Bumbaran, Lanao del Sur. She is 39 years old. Orly is married and has 2 infant children. To make a living, Orly owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) store, selling food and daily-use products in the local community. Orly has been engaged in her business for more than 3 years and earns approximately 9,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Orly joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Orly has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used as working capital, and to purchase additional inventory. Orly is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Orly from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.
